file_content.text: Great. With the force field down, we should be able to break the door open. On three. One... two... three!
Well done, Sith! Now... wait a moment. You're Jaesa Willsaam, aren't you?
That's right, Master Timmns.
I thought I sensed a serene and tempered presence through the door.
I used to be.
Any regrets, my dear? Joining up with this rogue?
None. I completely believe in what we're doing. You should, too.
Jaesa and I are doing things a bit against the grain.
She speaks the truth.
Sounds interesting. But I haven't lived this long by trusting Sith. I'd like to call your attention to the computers in here.
This Jedi is not to be trusted.
You misspeak, Jaesa.
That's too bad. You're going to have to put a lot of trust in me. Care to look at the computers in here?
Most days, no. I believe all beings have a great capacity to change.
Your naivete never ceases to amuse me.
How silly.
I can see I'm going to have my hands full with you.
Absolutely not, Jedi. Not when I get to meet and destroy obnoxious fools like you.
We have more important matters to attend to.
Enough talk.
That we do, Sith.
A woman after my own heart.
Delightful.
Yes, you seem to deserve each other.
Now, before you think to fight me, Sith, I suggest you inspect the computer banks in here.
Now that I have access to the records room, you are no longer safe.
Prepare to die, Jedi.
Don't be rash, Sith. First, I suggest you look at the computers in here.
Well done, Sith! Now, before you think to fight me, I suggest you look at the computers in here.
I'd say they've seen better days. Hmm, still smoking--I wonder who could have destroyed them.
You destroyed the computers so I couldn't get the information I need.
It was you.
Do you expect me to believe that Lord Melicoste did that?
The Darth we're after?
Luckily, he wasn't that smart. No, my friend, I destroyed them.
You just signed your death warrant.
I could kill you.
Don't be hasty.
I did it to make sure no one else sent by Darth Baras could succeed. That is, after you and I stop Lord Melicoste.
Now I'm the only one who knows where to go. Our goals are one, even if our motives vary. I suggest a partnership.
I'll keep my anger from consuming me, Jedi. For now. Once the deed is done, we are enemies again.
Not happy about this.
So no victory celebration, then? Too bad.
Tell me where Darth Ekkage's cell is, and we can part ways.
Stop the games.
Sorry. I can't be sure you won't attack me once you know.
I have no quarrel with you, Timmns. Let's work together.
Happily.
How unexpectedly amiable. Still, maybe a bit of caution.
All I'll tell you is that we're headed for Deep Prison. The exact location of Darth Ekkage's cell remains my secret.
In good faith, I'll point you to her assassins. You can make sure they remain locked up while I get access to the Deep Prison.
For the time being, I won't cut you open.
That will do, for now.
I'm thankful. You'll see, it makes sense to do it this way.
How do I know you'll make good on your promise?
Can I trust you?
Because it's practical, and I am nothing if not practical.
How about you deal with the assassins and I move to the next sector?
Why should I be the one?
Because I suspect you'll have slightly better rapport with your fellow Sith.
You might get the assassins to back down without a fight. Me? Not so much. Here are the coordinates.
Holo me when you're done, and we'll get together and face the Darths. It really will take both of us.
I have returned, Jedi. The power stations are down.
Still in here, in case you were worried. You might want to get around to taking out those power stations.
Hello out there. A word, please. I am Jedi Master Somminick Timmns.
This is not your day, Jedi. I am Sith, and I need to get inside that room.
I have bad news for you.
I can sense your presence and nature. I even know who you are.
Come out of there, friend, so we can talk properly.
We are allies. Open the door.
Good try, but I sense your nature. I know you are Sith. I even know who you are.
[Remain quiet]
I know you're there. I can feel your presence. What's more, I know who you are.
Many years past, I was the Padawan of Master Nomen Karr. He and I forged a bond through the Force.
I know about your confrontation with Master Karr, and what you did to him.
I should have killed that miserable old man when I had the chance.
He's lucky I spared him.
Does Master Karr fare well?
How is he?
He's never been the same, and he no longer communes with the Force.
Your Master begged like a coward and died like a dog.
He was pathetic.
Master Karr succumbed to darkness, I know. Hard to imagine such a strong Jedi reduced to such a condition.
Much has happened since my conflict with Karr. I have remorse over my actions.
I regret killing him.
He drifted away from the light. If it hadn't been you, it would have been someone else.
Sorry, the name doesn't ring a bell.
Who?
Stop pretending. You were sent by Darth Baras to confront him.
Ever since you defeated Karr and took Jaesa Willsaam, the Jedi Council has been keeping track of you.
We know you are no longer aligned with Darth Baras and are, in fact, here to stop Lord Melicoste from freeing Darth Ekkage.
Though Baras is my enemy, I'm still Sith.
I'm still loyal to the Empire.
I expect nothing else. But your arrival here tells me something.
Nice to see you Jedi aren't always in the dark.
Good for you.
You'll find we are not as inept as your former master may have suggested.
I can neither confirm nor deny your statement.
Maybe, maybe not.
I don't need confirmation; your presence at this door tells me everything.
It's a dead end, Sith. To follow Lord Melicoste, you need information from the computers in this room, but the door has been fused.
I came for the same reason. I got the information, but Lord Melicoste's commandos trapped me in here.
Outmatched by mere commandos. Not your proudest day.
How pathetic.
Oh, I don't know, there were quite a lot of them, and I held my own.
Supply me with the destination and I will stop him for you.
Tell me where to go.
Great idea. I can be satisfied that my mission was a success, as I slowly die of starvation. No thanks.
Tell me how I can break you out.
I'll free you.
Our combined strength, striking the door from both sides simultaneously, could break the physical seal.
Trouble is there's a fail-safe force field that makes even that impossible. Now, if you were to take out that force field....
If I do this, you'll give me access to the information I need.
You'll scratch my back.
You have my word.
What is entailed?
Hurry up.
There are several power stations feeding this installation. Destroy them, and the force field will not engage.
Then you and I can break through this door, and you can access the prisoner reports.
First, I'll see to it you die.
After killing you.
If you think you'll have time to waste fighting me... it's your call.
I agree.
Glad to hear it.
We can help each other.
Good thinking, Jedi.
It does appear that we need one another.
Scour the area and destroy the power stations. Then return and start banging on the door. We'll work it out.
I'll be waiting. After all, where am I going to go?
Ever since you defeated Karr and killed Jaesa Willsaam, the Jedi Council has kept track of you.
